Overall, I really enjoyed using the app and have contemplated extending my free trial to a monthly subscription. I would rate the app a 4 out of 5. As a 2nd year grad student, that has a full-time job, runs a small business and is living through a pandemic, I found the Headspace app to be the perfect resource for learning how to manage time for relaxation, self-care and stress management. The Headspace app‚Äôs engaging content, user friendly interface, and personally customizable dashboard enabled a hassle free and positive experience. Regarding areas for improvement, I think monthly/annual subscription rates can be negotiated. $13 dollars a month not including in-app purchases is quite high in comparison to similar apps that cost around 3-5 dollars. I think Headspace can expand user accessibility by providing a much larger language selection, as well as incorporating content and instructors that demonstrate diversity, equity and inclusion specifically regarding ableism and age. In the book, Working with Adolescents : A Guide for Practitioners, Julie Anne Laser and Nicole Nicotera explain that teenagers on average spend at least 10 hours each day interacting via social media platforms and the internet. The authors recognize that although media usage among adolescents may present risks for youth, media also presents benefits and can foster community, accessibility to information that impacts youth knowledge and useful programs that teach adolescents how to deal with depression and chronic fatigue. Due to our current life circumstances with the COVID-19 pandemic withthe exception of few educational institutions and workplace settings, life in this day and age has transitioned from in person activities to life online. The impact of burn out, stress, physical and mental health concerns on youth and adolescents has dramatically increased. Apps like Headspace offer youthaccessible ways to foster stress management, increase mental and physical health, practice self-care techniques and learn about mindful meditation strategies. As Laser and Nocoteradiscuss, messages received via media have effects on adolescent behavior. In this case, Headspace fosters the belief that individuals can and should create life-changing habits that promote individual and community mental health and wellbeing.

Headspace is a very easy app to get around, has many options for children and teens, is accessible, and visually appealing. The app is however expensive (if they don‚Äôt register with a nonprofit partner), and may not be stimulating enough to keep children coming back. Strategies such as yoga, meditation, and breathing techniques ‚Äúare helpful for promoting well-being and resilience in youth‚Äù and Headspace allows teens to have access to skill building resources that they can take with them wherever they go (Laser & Nicotera, 2021). This access can be incredibly helpful for children who have experienced trauma, as they may not feel comfortable meditating within a large group. Headspace allows them the opportunity to do it on their own in whatever space they feel the most safe in. Meditation and mindfulness training are extremely effective interventions for those who have experienced trauma because they ‚Äúenlist the whole person, and not just the mind‚Äù, as ‚Äútrauma affects both the mind and body‚Äù (Laser & Nicotera, 2021). Headspace has exceeded in the way in which it allows ‚Äòregular‚Äô people to access training and skills about meditation that would have previously been harder to find. The issue however, has to do with the discipline and time commitment needed to truly benefit from the effects of regular practice. Many of the studies that Headspace mentions on its website state the benefits associated with mindfulness for youth. The issue is that in all of these studies, the meditation or mindfulness activities were led by researchers or other people who were able to hold the participants accountable, or remind them to participate. Headspace does offer the choice to be reminded once a day by the app, but it is easy to ignore. I believe that Headspace is very beneficial when used regularly. However, when used sporadically, the effects of mindfulness techniques are fleeting, and truly incorporating those skills into everyday life becomes less attainable. Overall, Headspace is a well-rounded app for adolescents, and may help them alleviate some of their stress or anxiety, in a calming and very accessible manner.
